join_backend
  • API Reference
  • View page source

API Reference

Diese Dokumentation beschreibt die verschiedenen Komponenten der Projekt-API, organisiert nach Django-Apps.

Join App (join_app)

Diese App beinhaltet die Kernlogik für Tasks, Kontakte usw.

Models:

class join_app.models.Subtask(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Model

Represents a subtask associated with a parent Task.

task

The parent task this subtask belongs to. Deletes subtask if the parent task is deleted. Can be accessed via task.subtasks.

Type:

ForeignKey to Task

title

The title or description of the subtask (max 50 chars). Required.

Type:

CharField

complete

Indicates whether the subtask is completed. Defaults to False.

Type:

BooleanField

exception DoesNotExist

Bases: ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MultipleObjectsReturned

Bases: MultipleObjectsReturned

complete

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

id

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>
task

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

task_id
title

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

class join_app.models.Task(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Model

Represents a task created by a registered User.

Contains details about the task, its status, priority, assignments, and relationship to the owning user.

user

The user who created and owns this task. Deletes task if the user is deleted. Can be accessed via user.tasks.

Type:

ForeignKey to User

title

The title of the task (max 50 chars). Required.

Type:

CharField

category

The category of the task (max 50 chars). Required.

Type:

CharField

description

A detailed description of the task. Required.

Type:

TextField

dueDate

The due date for the task.

Type:

IntegerField

position

A field potentially used for ordering or positioning tasks. Required.

Type:

IntegerField

prio

The priority level of the task. Limited to choices: “Low”, “Medium”, “Urgent”. Required.

Type:

CharField

status

The current status of the task. Limited to choices: “todo”, “inProgress”, “awaitFeedback”, “done”. Required.

Type:

CharField

assignTo

Contacts assigned to this task. A task can be assigned to multiple contacts, and contacts can have multiple tasks. Required (blank=False). Can be accessed via contact.tasks_list.

Type:

ManyToManyField to UserContact

exception DoesNotExist

Bases: ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MultipleObjectsReturned

Bases: MultipleObjectsReturned

assignTo

Accessor to the related objects manager on the forward and reverse sides of a many-to-many relation.

In the example:

class Pizza(Model):
    toppings = ManyToManyField(Topping, related_name='pizzas')

Pizza.toppings and Topping.pizzas are ManyToManyDescriptor instances.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

prio

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

status

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

subtasks

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

title

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

user

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

class join_app.models.UserContact(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Model

Represents a contact associated with a specific registered User.

Stores personal details for a contact linked to a user account.

user

The user who owns this contact. Deletes contact if the user is deleted. Can be accessed via user.contacts.

Type:

ForeignKey to User

name

The name of the contact. Optional.

Type:

CharField

email

The email address of the contact. Optional.

Type:

EmailField

phone

The phone number of the contact. Optional.

Type:

CharField

shortcut

A short identifier or initials for the contact (max 2 chars). Optional.

Type:

CharField

color

A color code (e.g., hex like #RRGGBB) associated with the contact. Optional.

Type:

CharField

In the example:

    toppings = ManyToManyField(Topping, related_name='pizzas')

Pizza.toppings and Topping.pizzas are ManyToManyDescriptor instances.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

class join_app.api.views.SubtaskDetailView(**kwargs)[source]

Bases: RetrieveUpdateDestroyAPIView

API view for retrieving, updating, or deleting a single Subtask instance.

Handles GET, PUT, PATCH, and DELETE requests for a specific subtask, identified by its primary key in the URL.

serializer_class

The serializer used for subtask data.

Type:

SubtaskSerializer

queryset

Base queryset. Note: Permissions must be configured to ensure users can only access/modify subtasks belonging to tasks they own.

Type:

QuerySet

permission_classes

Recommended: [IsAuthenticated] and custom permission to check ownership via the parent task.

Type:

list

class join_app.api.views.SubtaskListCreateView(**kwargs)[source]

Bases: ListCreateAPIView

API view for listing contacts owned by the current user or creating a new contact.

Handles GET requests to list contacts and POST requests to create a new contact for the currently authenticated user.

serializer_class

The serializer used for contact data.

Type:

UserContactSerializer

get_queryset()[source]

Overrides the default queryset to return only subtasks belonging to the specified parent task (via URL’s ‘task_id’), ensuring the parent task belongs to the currently authenticated user.

perform_create(serializer)[source]

Overrides the default creation behavior to associate the new subtask with the correct parent task identified by ‘task_id’ in the URL.

Ensures the parent task belongs to the current user before saving.

serializer_class

alias of SubtaskSerializer

class join_app.api.views.UserTaskListCreateView(**kwargs)[source]

Bases: ListCreateAPIView

API view for listing tasks owned by the current user or creating a new task.

Handles GET requests to list tasks and POST requests to create a new task for the currently authenticated user.

serializer_class

The serializer used for task data.

Type:

TaskSerializer

get_queryset()[source]

Get the list of items for this view. This must be an iterable, and may be a queryset. Defaults to using self.queryset.

This method should always be used rather than accessing self.queryset directly, as self.queryset gets evaluated only once, and those results are cached for all subsequent requests.

You may want to override this if you need to provide different querysets depending on the incoming request.

(Eg. return a list of items that is specific to the user)

perform_create(serializer)[source]
serializer_class

alias of TaskSerializer

User Authentication App (user_auth_app)

Diese App ist verantwortlich für Benutzerregistrierung, Login und Profile.

Models:

class user_auth_app.models.UserProfile(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Model

Extends the standard Django User model using a one-to-one relationship.

This model provides a way to associate additional profile information with a User, although currently it only holds the direct link.

user

A one-to-one link to the corresponding Django User instance. If the User is deleted, this UserProfile will also be deleted due to on_delete=models.CASCADE.

Type:

OneToOneField to User

exception DoesNotExist

Bases: ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MultipleObjectsReturned

Bases: MultipleObjectsReturned

id

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>
user

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a one-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Restaurant(Model):
    place = OneToOneField(Place, related_name='restaurant')

Restaurant.place is a ForwardOneToOneDescriptor instance.

user_id

Serializers:

class user_auth_app.api.serializers.LogInSerializer(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Serializer

Serializer for user login validation.

Accepts email and password, validates them against existing User accounts, and performs authentication. Does not directly map to a model for saving.

validate(data)[source]

Validates user credentials (email and password).

Checks if a user with the given email exists and if the provided password is correct for that user using Django’s authentication system.

Parameters:

data (dict) – Dictionary containing ‘email’ and ‘password’ keys.

Returns:

The validated data dictionary, with the authenticated ‘user’

object added under the ‘user’ key if validation succeeds.

Return type:

dict

Raises:

serializers.ValidationError – If the email does not exist or the password is incorrect.

class user_auth_app.api.serializers.RegistrationSerializer(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: ModelSerializer

Serializer for user registration.

Handles validation of registration data, creation of a new User instance with a properly hashed password, creation of an associated ‘self’ UserContact, and triggering the creation of default contacts and tasks for the new user. Includes password confirmation field.

class Meta[source]

Bases: object

extra_kwargs = {'password': {'write_only': True}}
fields = ['username', 'email', 'password', 'repeated_password', 'first_name', 'last_name']
model

alias of User

save()[source]

Creates the User account, hashes the password, and performs post-registration setup.

Post-registration setup includes creating a UserContact for the user themselves and calling functions to create default contacts and tasks. Assumes password confirmation validation happens elsewhere (e.g., in a validate method or validate_repeated_password).

Returns:

The newly created and saved User instance.

Return type:

User

class user_auth_app.api.serializers.UserProfileSerializer(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: ModelSerializer

Serializer for the UserProfile model.

Handles serialization and deserialization of UserProfile instances. Currently includes all fields from the UserProfile model.

class Meta[source]

Bases: object

fields = '__all__'
model

alias of UserProfile

Views:

class user_auth_app.api.views.LogInView(**kwargs)[source]

Bases: APIView

API view for handling user login requests.

Accepts POST requests with user credentials (e.g., email/username, password). If authentication is successful via the LogInSerializer, it logs the user in (using Django’s session framework), generates/retrieves an authentication token, and returns user details along with the token. Allows access from any user without prior authentication.

authentication_classes = []
permission_classes = [<class 'rest_framework.permissions.AllowAny'>]
post(request)[source]

Handles POST request to authenticate and log in a user.

Parameters:

request (Request) – The incoming HTTP request containing user credentials in the request body.

Returns:

An HTTP Response.

  • 200 OK: If login is successful, returns a JSON object containing the auth token and user details (‘token’, ‘username’, ‘first_name’, ‘last_name’).

  • 400 Bad Request: If authentication fails or data is invalid, returns a JSON object with errors.

Return type:

Response

class user_auth_app.api.views.RegistrationView(**kwargs)[source]

Bases: APIView

API view for handling new user registrations.

Accepts POST requests with user registration data (e.g., username, email, password, first_name, last_name). If validation is successful, creates a new user, generates an authentication token, and returns user details along with the token. Allows access from any user.

permission_classes = [<class 'rest_framework.permissions.AllowAny'>]
post(request)[source]

Handles POST request to register a new user.

Parameters:

request (Request) – The incoming HTTP request containing user registration data in the request body.

Returns:

An HTTP Response.

  • 200 OK: If registration is successful, returns a JSON object containing the auth token and user details (‘token’, ‘username’, ‘email’, ‘first_name’, ‘last_name’).

  • 400 Bad Request: If the provided data is invalid, returns a JSON object with validation errors.

Return type:

Response
